Expectation1: Ensure the safe and punctual operation of the subway train.
Situation1: A critical alert for a brake system malfunction has just appeared, requiring an immediate report and stop.
Situation2: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Story: I glanced at the control panel as the train sped through the tunnel, my mind half on the tracks and half on the family ceremony waiting for me that evening. The alert flashed red—brake system malfunction. My training as a subway operator kicked in: I had to report this immediately, stop the train, and ensure everyone’s safety. But the clock on the dashboard reminded me of the time. My family would be gathering soon, the puja about to begin. I was expected to be there, dressed in my best, chanting prayers with them. Missing it would disappoint my parents and break a promise I’d made to myself to honor our traditions. My hands hovered over the controls, heart pounding. The weight of my uniform pressed against my skin, but so did the memory of my mother’s hopeful smile as she laid out my kurta this morning. The train rumbled on, the alert insistent, and I felt torn in two—between duty to my passengers and devotion to my family and faith.
